For about a month now I have been putting out dry dog food for the local raccoons. I live in a average residential single home neighborhood. It has amazed me how many different animals come through during the night. One raccoon mother has 4 kits. 4 days ago I got a small kiddie pool with a package of floating bath toys. In the morning the toys are scattered all over the place. It is fun to watch...
They heads are on a swivel too, listening and watching for trouble. Some of them do not play well with others... But I find it enjoyable...

I've convinced a colony of raccoons to visit my house nightly through efforts made early spring 2020. While fostering an actual relationship with them could be more difficult given their preoccupation for finding food and good shelter and the uncertainty of humans at large oh and cars and their short life span they have been convinced of my relative safety through long hours and months of careful offerings with continued advances in closing the distance. They're largely very sociable with each other when food isn't a concern yet still harbor territorial misgivings depending on their age, sex, family status and current claims to access. I've gathered a small number of them into my favoring while a decent number of others still merely take advantage of the excess available food. They can come to understand words, especially when they're consistent to a certain pitch. They're also, from my experience so far, careful about leaving refuse behind once they invest in a location. It's where they eat and cross paths so I imagine most times they prefer to do their leavings in private out of the way places.

What I find so nice about them and other regional wildlife is the degree you can gain something back from fostering their interests. While they're all rascals, every last creature, they return something with considerable access. Given how difficult it has to be for animals to live in a human structured world I'm given to feel obligated to be as charitable as possible. Veritasium had shared a good experience with squirrels and such, finding them a more excellent source of inspiration than just birds.

Can someone help me out with Common (Asian) House Geckos? I dunno if they're just underappreciated or understudied...

I've lived with them my entire life since they're everywhere in all the houses I've lived in, I've always thought of them as "free" pets. Anyway, I tried looking up info on them one day and all sources I could check list them as carnivores but they eat rice on a daily basis, they've been raiding the trash my entire life. There's also no mention of them being able to change color.

I've tried asking around in forums and most people had the theory that rice looks like maggots, but no, they also know that we keep rice in rice cooker appliances, aside from them raiding the trash. They also know which food they can/cannot eat inside the trash bins. I started regularly feeding them as an experiment and they show up almost on a schedule, at lunch. Since they live with humans, it makes sense that it was only a matter of time before they adapted to eating human food.

For the color changing. I've only witnessed the lizards changing twice, but still, I couldn't find any mention of this anywhere... Most, if not all, outdoor house geckos (yeah, they are still in the premises but outdoors) are darker in color and may also have bumpy skin, assuming it's for camouflage. But every indoor house gecko is lighter in color, as shown in Wikipedia. I've been wondering if they were separate species but I couldn't find any info at all about the darker ones that are outside. Turns out they're the same lizard. Once they are inside, in the shade, they turn from a dark color into the regular color and may also lose the bumps on their skin.

So yeah, either these creatures are underappreciated or just severely understudied. They are well-adapted to living indoors (or in the vicinity of houses) and they're pretty much everywhere in the city. They are omnivores that can change color, Wikipedia and all other sites I've seen on the internet don't list them as such. https://i.imgur.com/piYVVN7.jpg (a lizard trying out my lunch...)

Raccoons are adorable! Maybe we could use them to help with food waste since they already eat from the trash. They could eat any food thrown away so it doesn't end up in landfills producing greenhouse gases (if food waste was a country, it would be the third largest producer of greenhouse gases after China and the U.S.)

We really need to learn to cohabitate with these animals- even the crocodiles and snakes. I think we could come up with ways for both the animals and the people living in these cities to be happy. Maybe specific areas of cities with Macaques could be turned into open sanctuaries/parks for the monkeys, encouraging them to hang out there where there are trees and jungle gyms and food for them. If we give these animals a designated space in the city that has everything they need, they will be less likely to venture out and potentially bother or attack people and their pets.

Maybe people could find a way to block off the polluted rivers from small animals like dogs and cats- and instead just start a feeding program for the crocodiles so they don't ever have to kill people's pets for food.

Ideally, we would get these animals back to their natural environments, but for the ones who lost theirs due to human encroachment, we really ought to set up a designated area for them that mimicks their natural habitat. We could even vaccinate them to prevent disease spread to pets and people. Obviously, both people and the animals would have to sacrifice a bit (humans would sacrifice money and effort, and the animals would sacrifice freedom), but I think it would be worth it.

I wish number 4 was true but it isnt, at least not in Australia. Flying foxes in Australia are having a really bad time and their numbers are declining. The ones in urban environments face so many dangers. They are don't cope particularly well in cities despite the food available. They get stuck in fruit tree netting and on barbed wire, try to land on power lines and get electrocuted (birds perch on a single line so are usually fine but fruitbats are big enough to touch two lines so they get zapped), they get hit by cars, and they get stuck in yards and balconies and all kinds of gaps in buildings bcus they cant take off from the ground they have to drop into the air.
Pls watch and support if you can channels like Batzilla the Bat and Megabattie who run independent fruitbat rescues in Australia the fruitbats they save are the most precious and adorable creatures 💕 who are also super important for their ecosystems bcus as well as fruit they eat nectar and pollen and they are essential pollinators for many plants and trees.

The Macaques of Gibraltar are also a tourist attraction; but one of the keepers there told us that they are a matriarchal clan in which the younger or subservient give the leader their food; so tourists, by feeding them, have taught them that humans are lower in the pecking order, which is why they get mad when they aren't given what they want. The best way to avoid the clash is to keep your picnic or your belongings in your bag and keep that attached to your body (backpack, over-shoulder purse strap). What they don't see, they don't want.

In Australia, I'd add the only sharks that scare me - Bull Sharks.  They love man made residential canals & places like Sydney Harbour.  They have even adapted to fresh water!  Bull Sharks have been found 126km upstream in fresh water on the Brisbane River.  But they, unlike most sharks, are super aggressive & love the taste of "long pig".  So don't swim in the canals of the Gold Coast or Brisbane River & be careful swimming in Sydney Harbour if you visit us!  PS: My small Patreon contribution is so worth it!

I'm surprised that you didn't mention the synurbic organism which has been hanging 'round humans for quite possibly our entire urban evolutionary history (& before).

Rattus Rattus_ - that amazingly adaptable social *Rodent, which lives in staggeringly huge numbers within our major cities (approximately 2.6 Million in New York City, for example), is remarkably intelligent for the small size of it's brain, easily capable of learning & communicating about food resources - not to mention dangers in the immediate vicinity. They've even demonstrated concepts like altruism (with caged rats being given food by packmates) & fairness (with a rat given large quantities of a preferred food, sharing with one given a staple, boring food).

Unfortunately, wild rats are emphatically vectors for hundreds of lethal diseases (including many nasty viruses, like Rabies, Hantavirus, as well as many bacterial pathogens like - indirectly through fleas, ticks & lice - the terrifying Bubonic Plague⊕), plenty of which can be dangerous - even lethal - to humans, so major efforts are underway to eradicate them.

Given their vast numbers, though, this isn't likely to be significantly effective any time soon. ; )~

⊕ Yes, unfortunately Yersinia Pestis still exists in places like India, Pakistan & Afghanistan, where the modern medical infrastructure is largely nonexistent.

The other day a few blocks from me a man was apparently eating a sandwich in his backyard and the momma bear waltzed right up to him, thankfully he just tossed her his sandwich and went inside and everything was fine!

Thanks to the lockdown in the city I live (central Europe) we now have ferrets, those big forest pigeons, kind of small falcons, hedgehogs roaming free on the lawns, yesterday I saw a peasant just strolling along my street! My best raccoon story has to do with a family of prison raccoons. At that prison the cats that came to the trash dumpsters at night were kind of  vicious. So much so that it was a good idea to have security walk with you to empty the trash (or leave it for the morning orderly). But when this family of raccoons were at the trash dumpster the cats would sit quietly at the dumpster and wait for the raccoons toss them tidbits of eatable trash. It was kind of cute, but not a dinner you wanted to disturb. (Or report because then there would be an attempt to capture and remove the cats and raccoons)

Rachel Carson, an author of a book called Silent Spring. Where she made a bunch of totally unsupported and as it turned out, totally wrong, assertions about DDT. She made some crap up because, activism. Because she was such a well known author of activism environmentalism, people just took her at her word. She was personally and almost solely responsible for DDT being banned world wide, causing the deaths of millions and millions of people in Africa due to malaria.
